docs.lead_paragraph: Finally, 20 months after the overvalued dollar began its long slide, there are scattered but unmistakable signs that America's trade picture is beginning to improve. A declining dollar should make foreign goods more costly to Americans and American goods less costly to customers abroad. A spot-check by correspondents of The New York Times indicates that companies and consumers here and abroad are altering their buying and selling behavior in response to the dollar's diminished value. Reports on Sales Abroad Foreigners are buying more Kodak film. Johnson & Johnson, the pharmaceutical company, says its sales abroad have increased appreciably. Monsanto is shipping more herbicides, and a big French supermarket chain is pushing American food products.

headline.main: U.S. TRADE SCENE SLOWLY IMPROVES AFTER 20-MONTH DECLINE OF DOLLAR

docs.snippet: Finally, 20 months after the overvalued dollar began its long slide, there are scattered but unmistakable signs that America's trade picture is beginning to improve.   A declining dollar should make foreign goods more costly to Americans and American...

docs.lead_paragraph: Thousands of patients with rare neuromuscular disorders are suffering renewed contortions of the eyes, face, neck and other parts of the body because their supply of experimental medicine was cut off when its only manufacturer was unable to obtain liability insurance. Many who had been faring well are now reverting to functional blindness, unable to read, work, drive or venture outdoors. Others can no longer speak; some suffer debilitating muscle spasms that contort their faces or necks. Desperate patients are traveling to Canada or England to obtain the experimental drug, made of botulinum toxin. It is the only medicine that gives them satisfactory relief. A few are already resorting to risky, disfiguring surgery as the only alternative to the missing medicine.

headline.main: LOSS OF DRUG RELEGATES MANY TO BLINDNESS AGAIN

docs.lead_paragraph: Within a year, a drug should become available in France for use under physicians' supervision that both blocks and terminates pregnancy, according to a World Health Organization official. If a woman wishes to avoid pregnancy after intercourse or if she has missed a menstrual period and believes she may be pregnant,a single pill would initiate menstruation, sweeping the egg cell out of her system. Dr. Jose Barzelatto, the director of W.H.O.'s program on human reproduction, noted that in such a case the woman could not tell whether she was actually pregnant. The new drug is still known only by the designation RU 486, given by its developer, the Roussel-Uclaf Company, a French affiliate of Hoechst-Roussel Pharmaceuticals, based here in Switzerland.

headline.main: SCIENTISTS DEVELOPING A NEW DRUG THAT BLOCKS AND HALTS PREGNANCY

byline.original: By WALTER SULLIVAN, Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: At a time when medical experts increasingly recognize the element of compassion as an essential aid in the healing process, several circumstances in New York City's hospitals continue to make them among the worst when it comes to treating patients like people, not just bed numbers or diseases. Mr. Leonard's back surgery, for example, was unquestionably a success. He had entered New York University Hospital in mid-September with such pain in his right leg that he could hardly even lie down. On the first day after surgery, he was able to walk without discomfort. Then his troubles began: a fever that soared to over 104, a possible spot of pneumonia and urinary retention, all followed by an itchy rash that covered him from head to toe.
